content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-self-profile by @Wesley Wiser and michaelwoerister: anything to report?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , sorry I’m a little late. I was just working on a write-up for an issue we may want to discuss today. (Add a :wave: to show you are here!)
(or, the fact that it has a write-up may mean that we will want to instead discuss it tomorrow.)
hmm
when is our next Friday planning meetign scheduled? I cannot find it on calendar
Ah, Friday 4 June is next planning meeting

so that’s a good way to open the

Announcements
• Next friday 4 June is a planning meeting for our friday steering/design meetings. Get your proposals in at proposal site
• I'm assembling an agenda for the next CTCFT meeting on 2021-06-21 and I want to encourage folks who have thoughts to file issues or reach out :)
Oh here’s a fun announcement
• Compiler team alum @mw is coming back to the team
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "LLVM plugin support in Rust" compiler-team#419
    • "Promote aarch64-apple-ios-sim to Tier 2" compiler-team#428
    • "Write text output files to stdout if options like -o - or --emit asm=- are provided" compiler-team#431

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Make TypeFolder::fold_* return Result" compiler-team#432
    • "Introduce ty::WhereClause to align chalk and rustc dyn representation" compiler-team#433
    • "Force warnings on lints " compiler-team#434

• Accepted MCPs
    • "Update the existing musl targets to be dynamically linked." compiler-team#422
    • "A --temps-dir option for specifying where the intermediate files are written" compiler-team#423

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Add functions Duration::try_from_secs_{f32, f64}" rust#82179
    • "Move UnwindSafe, RefUnwindSafe, AssertUnwindSafe to core" rust#84662
    • "stabilize member constraints" rust#84701
    • "stabilize int_error_matching" rust#84910
    • "stabilize const_fn_unsize" rust#85078
WG checkins

@WG-self-profile checkin by @Wesley Wiser and michaelwoerister:

We've had a few small PRs to measureme but no major changes during this time.

Oh, I have one last announcement, sort of a PSA that changd my life:

  • If you tweak the RUSTC_LOG settings (see #wg-traits > log folding) then VSCode will allow you to fold your logs automatically; very useful if they have a lot of indentated
hmm, where in linked thread is the concrete thing that is impliemented?
That looks interesting
presently you have to apply this patch
okay, it is the patch
(that’s not how I interpret “tweak an env var setting”)
Before we go to next part of meeting
(namely, backport nominatins)
I want to talk about the status of incr-comp, and what we will do for the 1.53-stable release
(which is the next release, due out June 17th)
I have a write-up. Insert Pascal quote here about not having time to make it shorter.
(Blaise Pascal, not the Programming Language)
Maybe we can all take… five minutes to read that write-up ?

pnkfelix said:

(that’s not how I interpret “tweak an env var setting”)

(I mistyped)

(if you’ve been following #t-compiler > unstable variants for #[non_exhaustive] enums? , the write-up will be mostly redundant, and you can probably just jump to my twitter poll)

Quick poll for developers who normally would be using an up-to-date Rust stable: Are you currently:

- Felix S K II (@pnkfelix)
how can I see the results?
oh noes
You have to vote to see the results
let me screen shot it
I guess I can just vote, there's enough votes it won't matter :)
I don't really have an answer
Where's the option "whatever version of rust x.py downloaded the last time I git pulled"?
right :)
I think that's beta
image.png
(Note the conditional, “for developers who would normally be using up-to-date Rust stable."
(and therefore, x.py users, as automatic beta users, are not meant to be part of the poll. But of course none of this is scientific at all, I’m sure many of the answers were accidental)
so it seems like most folks are just using the latest stable
per the poll
(which is what I would expect)
there were follow up polls
I’ll screenshot those too now
You'd think Rust devs on Twitter would be over representative of people who follow Rust news and yet 30% still said "why not 1.52.0?". Very interesting.
image.png

You'd think Rust devs on Twitter would be over representative of people who follow Rust news and yet 30% still said "why not 1.52.0?". Very interesting.

That tells me that we want to be conservative with our choices :)
image.png
so okay, now that I’ve made you all sit through that write-up
here’s a real question: Should we actually attempt to resolve this question now, today? Or should we do a Friday meeting about it, tomorrow?
We could probably talk about this for an entire hour :grimacing:
I think this is an ok time to talk it over
We could take a poll really quick and see if there's strong agreement on what we want to do.
I kind of feel like we shouldn't spend an hour on it
If there's not, we could discuss tomorrow
Lets try to resolve it now
First up: What questions are there about the content of the write-up itself?
I had a question:
I saw niko added some to bottom
I've not been following the beta backport situation-- have we definitely decided against backporting those various PRs?
In discussion last week
I think there was general concern
about rushing
And that led me to conclude
that while we might pick and choose indivudal backports
we should not assume that all fixes will be backported en massse
there is too much risk associated with that number of changes
(Of course if that changes, if we do end up nominating and approving all for backport, in a natural fashion)
(then that would change calcuation here tremendously.)
But, for purposes of this conversation, I think it is best to assume that not 100% of the ICEs will get backports in 1.53

OK. I think this is a question of balancing risk versus convenience. We've chosen to generally take a quite conservative route here until now. We don't have any real data (right?) on whether folks remain affected by the unfixed ICEs.
That’s right. If we had more beta users, I’d feel more confident
but the twitter poll, unscientific as it is, indicates that far more people just jump straight to nightly
We have (1) data point of only one ICE encountered on beta (Carol).
and so while it seems like we are in a very good place w.r.t. the 1.54 release
That's certainly what I would do. beta is that weird netherworld -- for CI only -- in my mind.
we don’t know that much about the 1.53 release
As a point against relying on beta experience i and many others just skip beta in their ci too and run with stable and nightly a lot of the time.
there is one other interesting data point
Kyle Huey explicitly said
that they went back to 1.51
because they need incr-comp, and they were hitting the ICE
It could be that they tried beta, ran into another issue and then tried nightly and found it resolved. However, that's purely conjecture on my part.
they did not attempt to switch to the beta
It's what I'd expect most people to do
I asked Kyle if they tried to beta, and they said no
It's a bit annoying that people did not follow our guidance there, but I guess there's not much we can do
The whole basis for turning incr-comp off and adding RUSTC_FORCE_INCREMENTAL, and the blog post
was that we believe it is best practice not to go back to an older version
You won't be able to reach everybody
I wish we had better data about how many peopel did, nonetheless
Given that so few people seem to be running beta, I'm very hesitant to make any kind of decision based on the lack of reported ICEs from beta.
even if we had a way to notify people when they run rustup, which we don't
I think it's helpful to think of worst case scenarios
Let me attempt a quick straw poll now
In my mind, the worst case scenario is that we release 1.53 and have to release 1.53.1 turning off incremental again
Rustup growing a way to show advisories is something that would make sense regardless imo
Put :thumbs_up: or :thumbs_up: or :shrug: for each option
the 1.53 release (whatever it looks like) should not give people a reason to switch to an older stable release
Option: Put the RUSTC_FORCE_INCREMENTAL guard onto the 1.53-stable release
i.e. no ICEs
/me scrolls up to see how many people :wave: ‘d at beginning. Cc @T-compiler/meeting ^
Option: Let things just ride trains. No RUSTC_FORCE_INCREMENTAL on 1.53-stable

@mw people with large codebases will get hit by compilation speed issues with disabled incrcomp. People that encounter ICEs' first reaction will be to downgrade, but if they perceive a perf issue, that will also be their first act.
@pnkfelix this also means that incremental works by default?
Yes
@Esteban Küber that's true ...
It's worth noting we can change the error message to explicitly say: "If you encounter this ICE and want to avoid it, please try the 1.54 beta"
Option: Straw polls now are misleading. We should wait a week or two, after more beta backport decisions are made.
Or we find a way to get more data.
But I guess that's unlikely.
@mw the benefit we have is that enough people read the release notes that the new env flag will have a better chance of being known
Last week's backport decisions seemed to ride on whether we were going to do option 1 or not.
@Wesley Wiser ah, are you pointing out that there may be circular dependency here?
Yeah
I would also say there's some (potential) inconsistency -- i.e., if we opt not to backport, that is cautious, but if we then enable incremental -- is that not risky?
I guess there are different dimensions of risk, in that an ICE is not a miscompilation.
right
its far less risky than using old versions of compiler (IMO)
to be fair
Additionally, some of the fixes may have effects beyond incr comp
many people did report via twitter that incr-comp does not matter for their use case
e.g. the conductive cycle change
Whereas the ICE only affects incremental
okay we are now 36 minutes past the hour
OK, well, we had the straw poll :)

IMO if we release 1.53 with the env variable gate, it is pretty likely that people won't upgrade or will be hesitant to, saying 'well they still haven't fixed bugs' no matter how much we try to say "well but we actually have"
I think if we want to discuss this more, it would be helpful to have the "narratives" that people are using to make their decisions
e.g., simulacrum's narrative is there
I would find it helpful :)
There’s another question
At one point, I was planning to put up a blog post
First version was just to tell people “switch to the beta”
because everything in it would be fixedd
Obviously I threw out that plan
but
in terms of this “gathering narratives" thing
What would be the right channel to even get that info
hackmd doc
does a blog post work?
have people type them in :)
no, I mean the people here
oh oh
"why did you vote the way you did in the straw poll"
I see, I thought you wanted stories from our users who are not in this mtg
but now I see
different kind of narrative :)
okay
I'm just saying for complex decisions like this, there are various tradeoffs, I think it's useful to see "I think this outweights that, so I did X"
one last Q before we move on to regular agenda
Should we attempt to hold a friday meeting about this
I currently am thinking “no"
at least, not tomorrow
Does anyone here think we would benefit from continuing to discuss this tomorrow at this time slot?
I think we need to come to a conclusion soon or we're going to have (potentially) a large set of backports and little time for users to test beta.
(we obviously can have async discussion, probably in #t-compiler > unstable fingerprints - actually in 1.52 #84970 )
yeah I guess that feeds into the set of backport nominations that we’re about to dive into
I like @nikomatsakis's idea. that should give a more detailed overview of what people think and why
I think this might be more pressing since it decides what we're going to backport.
In which case, we might need to defer the rest of the agenda until tomorrow or next week if it can wait.
I also suspect we won’t get through our agenda today now anyway
I thnk discussing more is fine but only if we have some work into assessing the set of tradeoffs and the different viwes on how they add up, to give it some structure.
which means we should plan to use some of tomorrow’s Friday meeting for the remainder of todays agenda, potentially...
Otherwise I think we're likely to just go in circles rediscovering them :)
Okay. Maybe people can add their reasoning for why they voted the way they did onto the hackmd writeup ?
I think @nikomatsakis's suggestion is good. Is 15 minutes enough time to reasonably have that discussion?
I was assuming @nikomatsakis was saying that we should not attempt to have discussino now?
If not, maybe we should try to get through any other backports today and leave this question for tomorrow? That would also allow people to write their thoughts between now and then.
Yeah at this point I think what @Wesley Wiser wrote has to be our plan
Well, I assume if we are going to share our "narratives", there will be discussion after that? That's what I was referring to.
I meant people whould write their thoughts into the doc before the meeting
I think @Wesley Wiser and I are actually agreeing, but I’m not sure
so we can read them, discuss a bit, and then make a final decision on which one sounds most convincing
I think so :smile:
We can move on
i.e. : Everyone should write their thoughts into the doc before the Friday meeting tomorrow
(you can write it now, if you can do that and still pay attention here…)
agenda then

Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "have on_completion record subcycles" rust#85186
    • Fixes rust#83538, a P-high issue with the trait evaluation cache
    • approved by @Jack Huey
    • comment: perf comparison seems to indicate a tiny regression but the gain provided by this patch greatly make it worth
    • nominated by @nikomatsakis because these incremental failures are a big problem
we explicitly are not discussing this today

• "readd capture disjoint fields gate" rust#85564
    • opened by @pnkfelix
    • approved by @nikomatsakis
    • adds again a feature gate from PR rust##83521 to allow a beta backport
    • backport already discussed and approved? (see this comment)
(was this indeed unilaterally back ported…?)
I dont think so. Adding emojis now
actually
what I’m I talking about, I’m unilaterally approving for backport, right now

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • No beta nominations for T-libs-impl this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

• "Remove unstable --pretty flag" rust#83491
    • discussed last week, Felix added some comments, any reaction?
I think I am in the minority here
and in any case, since its all unstable, we can always put —pretty back later if we decide this was a mistake
(two-way door!)
so lets just let PR #83491 move forward, I think, unless someone besides me wants to object.)

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 3 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 2 of those are unassigned
  • 78 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 51 of those are unassigned
  • 6 P-critical, 0 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 2 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 2 P-critical, 46 P-high, 85 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "ICE when reifying function pointers to copy / copy_nonoverlapping using an if" rust#84297
    • also I-nominated (see below)
we should find an owner for this
T-lang discussed, I know
I guess since niko and I are the people with feet in both teams, either one of us is probably best to own this. I will take it.
I don't think we want implementation to support reifying intrinsics to a function pointer.
Personally I want to remove intrinsics
and just have lang items :)
(I'm not sure if that's possible or not in stable though, I forget)
(I suspect we cannot take time to discuss details of this here, in this meeting. Better to drive conversatin to github, or a dedicated zulip topic?)
But we can discuss that in the issue :)

• "Unstable fingerprints - what to do on beta (and stable)" rust#84970
    • comment from @pnkfelix : downgrade issue to P-high?
we obviously just spent ages discussing this
and it aint getting downgraded to P-high
next

• "Miscompilation on ARM-M with nightly-2021-04-23" rust#85351
    • regression from nightly nightly-2021-04-23 (therefore regression-from-stable-to-beta) on 2 different Tier ARM targets (thumbv8m and thumbv7em)
    • issue reporter mentions that it could affect other targets
    • @yroux submitted a fix to LLVM D103167, hopefully will be in LLVM 12.0.1
Oxide Computer folks reported this
it does seem like it is under control
but I would like for it to have an owner
maybe someone from @WG-llvm ?
I’m going to move along now, nonetheless

T-libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2021-05-25

A somewhat quiet week. Some PRs had performance runs performed on them, but the changes were merged despite this. Also, we still have issues with certain benchmarks being noisy.

Triage done by @rylev.

2 Regressions, 2 Improvements, 1 Mixed
0 of them in rollups

Regressions

Make building THIR a stealable query #85273

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 3.7% on incr-full builds of tuple-stress-check)
  • Work needed for other work to land. A performance run was performed, but still the change was allowed to land. I've asked why.

Implement the new desugaring from try_trait_v2 #84767

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 2.9% on full builds of cranelift-codegen-check)
  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -1.8% on full builds of deeply-nested-async-check)
  • A much larger performance hit than when the performance suite was run while the pull request was open. This is largely a performance regression with only one non-volatile benchmark showing improvement.
  • Biggest change seems to be in the mir_built query which seems to make sense given that probably more mir will be produced by this change.
  • Follow-up happening here.
(see also #t-compiler > proposed perf regression policy )

Improvements

  • fix deallocation of immutable allocations #85599
  • std: Attempt again to inline thread-local-init across crates #84876

Mixed

Avoid zero-length memcpy in formatting #85391

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 3.8% on incr-patched: println builds of cargo-opt)
  • Moderate improvement in instruction counts (up to -1.8% on full builds of deeply-nested-async-debug)
  • This seems to have some interactions with LLVM codegen that cause certain benchmarks to fluctuate in performance. These largely cancel each other out.

Nags requiring follow up

  • Follow-up:
    #84767.
is @rylev here?
I just wanted to check about the noisy benchmarks. But I can follow-up 1:1 with them
I'm here
Okay. I add put in an explicit section last week, I think, because the noise was indeed so bad
that I wanted to call it out separately
was it not that bad this week? Or did you just filter out the noisy cases, rather than list them on their own?
(PS, @rylev just pointed out to me that they're encountering incremental ICEs on nightly: #t-compiler/help > Incremental compilation issue )
I filed #85729 as a follow-up to the regressions from #85273

pnkfelix said:

Okay. I add put in an explicit section last week, I think, because the noise was indeed so bad

(the separate section was showing how certain benchmarks ping-pong, improvement->regression, due to noise in measurement)
I always filter out the noisy ones. There were 3-4 noisy cases I believe in the same benchmark
I see. Okay.
Lets talk more about that in #t-compiler/performance

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "ICE when reifying function pointers to copy / copy_nonoverlapping using an if" rust#84297
    • unassigned
    • nominated by @simulacrum (also for T-lang)
    • @tmiasko suggests to revert #81238 as short term solution
(we discussed this above, sort of.)
Lets maybe allocate a zulip topic for it
or is there one already?
I made one
#t-compiler > reifying function ptrs for intrinsics #84297

• "Preserve, clarify, and extend debug information" rust#83947
    • nominated by @pnkfelix
I nominated this one, because I wanted visibility on it, and also, I wanted to ask whether this sort of change is meant to go through MCP process or not
since its modifying CLI interface to rustc
(extending it, I guess, is more accurate)
but I dont recall if we’ve treated -C flags as a special case that can bypass MCP
I don’t think we do?
I think this needs an MCP
seems safest to assume it needs an MCP
it also needs more documentation on what it actually does :)
and really, debug info handling is a topic that needs more love overall
okay
I’ll write a comment saying as much

T-libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for T-libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
Hey that’s the whole agenda!
and we’re only 2 minutes overtime

Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! And please do try to:

  1. Write up your thoughts behind your stand-up poll (or just your thoughts even if you missed the poll), on the incr-comp writeup
  2. Do write-up the thoughts before tomorrow’s steering meeting
  3. We’ll use the steering meeting slot to try to make progress on the incr-comp Question
Thanks again! :wave:
Oh one more thing
there was a Q on the writeup

• How many known ICEs are still unfixed on nightly?
    * The table in [#84970][] suggests 1 out of 7
I think the one row that is “unfixed"
arguably shoud not be in the table at all? When I looked at the issue, it didn’t seem like it was a fingerprnit issue?
I’m speaking of "Incremental compilation ICE with from compiler-state-dependent overflow errors" #84963
oh wait
sorry, I didn’t read carefully enough
I think there are three
the bug reporter did indeed say there as a fingerprint issue there
I need to update the issue
is the fingerprint part of that issue addressed?
Which issue?
#84963
No, that issue still needs to be fixed
okay
thanks @Aaron Hill
There's also another EvaluatedToOk issue (which I've reproduced locally)
and somebody reported an item_children issue on a recent nightly
I'll update the issue list later today with the current state of things

Draft for next week's agenda:
https://hackmd.io/wCIbJPBKSxKeScnuh3dr2Q?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @WG-async-foundations nikomatsakis tmandry
  • @WG-traits by nikomatsakis Jack Huey
